Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: MicroFlotronics: Flexible Transparent, Pressure-Sensitive Microfluidic Films for Biomedical Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
There is an increasing demand for sensitive, flexible, and low-cost pressure sensing solutions for health monitoring, wearable sensing, robotic and prosthetic applications. This proposal describes a translational research plan to develop highly sensitive pressure sensing devices to map pressure distributions at an ultrafine spatial resolution. The proposed sensing technology offers a powerful alternative to the solid-state pressure sensors, by providing an unprecedented sensitivity and ultrafast response time in a completely transparent, flexible and adaptive platform. Potential applications can be integration with existing medical applications: given its low-cost and flexible design,the sensor can be readily integrated into existing medical devices (e.g., disposable catheters) for physiological pressure monitoring; and artificial skin with digital sensation: our ultrasensitive and flexible sensor film can be integrated onto the soft fingertip surface of a glove to stimulate the sense of touch.

This proposal intends to deliver the world first microfluidics-enabled flexible pressure-sensitive film for biomedical applications, as a powerful alternative to the existing solid-state pressure sensors. The proposed microflotronics sensors offer several unique advantages over existing pressure sensing technologies: ultrahigh sensitivity, low cost, rapid mechanical response, ultrathin profile, soft skin-like construct, stable sensing units, and optical transparency. The microfluidics-enabled sensing devices pioneered by this team have shown promise in an array of unconventional applications in which a minute amount of liquid sensing elements rapidly respond to an external load by altering the physical properties or geometries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the NSF I-Corps Program awarded in the Quarter 2014, several achievements have been summarized. Firstly, a start-up company, TacSense, LLC, has been set up within UC Davis Engineering Technology Translation Center. Secondly, one patent will be issued on Oct. 27th, 2015, and two US provisional patent applications have been submitted. Thirdly, two articles on the microfluidics-enabled flexible pressure sensing (MICS) principle have been published. Last but not limited, the educational opportunities on the emerging flexible tactile sensing and cutting-edge micro-nano engineering concepts have been provided to students through undergraduate-level class/research program in UC Davis.

  • TacSense, LLC was founded: TacSense, LLC was formed in the UC Davis Engineering Translational Technology Center, a UC based technology incubator. The technology was originally developed in Dr. Pan’s MiNI Lab at UC Davis based on the MICS principle. TacSense is strategically envisioned to become an innovative pressure sensor manufacturer and supplier by providing MICS solutions for a wide range of existing and emerging applications, including medical devices, robotics or consumer electronics, in which sensitive, flexible, and low-cost pressure sensing solutions are highly demanded. In the I-Corps program, TacSense found a niche in the field of the flexible pressure monitoring in medical device market, and also initialized its industrial partners for device prototype fabrications.  Meanwhile, TacSense is also exploring new market opportunities of unmet medical challenges for the proprietary MICS solutions, which can lead to long-term growth and profitability.
  • Patents: During the I-Corps Program, the patent of “Droplet-Based Capacitive Pressure Sensor”, 14/106,760 will be issued on Oct 27th, 2015. In addition, other two US provisional patent applications, “Liquid Column-Based Capacitive Normal/Shear Pressure/Force Sensor” with the application No. 61/916,196, and “Flexible Transparent Iontronic Film for Interfacial Capacitive Pressure Sensing” with the application No. 62/211,630, have been submitted.
  • Two journal publications: In order to further improve the device performance, and to export the new utilities and functionalities, innovative approaches by the cutting-edge micro-nanotechnology have been explored. As a result, one article has been published in the Journal of Advanced Materials (with the Impact Factor of 17.49), titled “Flexible Transparent Iontronic Film for Interfacial Capacitive Pressure Sensing”, in which a novel flexible and transparent iontroic film has been introduced to the pressure sensor as the sensing element. The introduce of the new material enables device fabrication process is fully compatible with the industrial-scale manufacturing, which passes the way to massive production at extremely low cost. In addition, by exploring the wearable flexible interface pressure monitoring direction, another paper has been submitted in the Journal of - Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) in Dec. 2014.
  • Educational outstretch and impact to the public: The PI is actively engaged in extending his research progress and providing education opportunities on the flexible tactile sensing, interfacial iontronics, and the emerging micro-nano engineering concepts, to students through an undergraduate-level class in UC Davis and a summer Global Research Experience in Advanced Technologies (GREAT) program in UC Davis Extension. 

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2015
Modified by: Tingrui Pan
